body: Thank you for the reported issue. Would you like to help up to fix this issue by submitting a pull request? We have [contributors guide](https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/blob/master/docs/internals/git-workflow.md) that is a good starting point. If you need any tip – let us know.

Hi @SilverFire ,
I can easily “remove the one sign”. The problem isn't the realisation, the problem is figuring out what's happening there and if I'm actually telling the truth.
Because I can’t fully understand the line 
`exec('DEL /F/Q ' . escapeshellarg($path), $lines, $deleteError);`
Well I know in general, but I only assume it should return 0 in `$deleteError` if there is no error. That’s why I suggested the last line to be return `$deleteError == 0;`
But really, someone with better understanding of this has to made the final decision.

As far as I see, [DEL does not return status code](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/22953027/batch-file-and-del-errorlevel-0-issue).

I think we can change `return $deleteError !== 0` to `return !is_file($path)`
That's additional stat call. We can do it for `exec` path only.

> That's additional stat call.

It's a fallback scenario, a code in catch block. I think it will not be called to often to affect performance.
Yes. Agree.
Excellent guys. Now what? It's your solution. It should be your PR right? Or should I do that to save your time?
We are always happy to see pull requests. In case you have time and eager to practice - you are welcome. Otherwise we'll do it ourself.
Ok, I'll do it then.

I tried to test your solution before the commit and your idea does’n work.
Let’s assume my example – adding non-existent file to the method.
When I’m in the catch part, because the PHP’s unlink() function didn’t work, Yii tries to delete the file using exec (btw why would exec del worked and unlink didn’t?). But then your checking if the file exists somehow presumes “when it doesn’t exist, it had to be deleted”, which is false. If already non-existent file is passed, it can’t be deleted and it should return false.
Right. The check should be prior to deleting it.
The `DEL` command reports success regardless if file was deleted or not so I guess we have to return file_exists($path);
Better to use `file_exists` instead of `is_file` btw.
unlink symlinks can be... hard on Windows
That's known issue that this is the only way to remove a symlink in non-pro versions of Windows 10.

and → && (code style)

The rest looks good to me.

issue.title: Fix #16183 when `yii\helpers\BaseFileHelper` sometimes returned wrong value
